source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Helichrysum
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Helichrysum. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Intermediate involucral bracts white, sometimes tinged with pink

Basal and at least lower stem leaves adaxially scabrous or slightly roughened by persistent short septate hairs or bristles (apparent at x10 magnification); rosette usually developed, or at least lower leaves broader and close-spaced; capitula mostly 25 mm diam. or more; plants typically of lowland to foothill heathy woodlands and forests, rarely in grasslands

Leaves essentially smooth adaxially, devoid of conspicuous septate multi-celled hairs; basal rosette not or rarely developed and lower leaves barely differing from mid-stem leaves; capitula mostly less than 25 mm diam.; plants chiefly of lowland grasslands and/or montane to alpine woodland or heath

Involucral bracts usually lemon-yellow or paler; aerial stems not or sparingly branched; leaves distinctly discolourous, upper surface glabrescent, lower surface with ± appressed cottony hairs, or, if ever ± concolourous then glabrescent throughout; apex acuminate, not mucronate; lower- to mid-stem leaves mostly longer than 4 cm; length:width ratio greater than 8; generally in grasslands on heavy soils, or riverine woodlands

Involucral bracts usually rich yellow to orange; aerial stems often freely branched; leaves ±  concolourous or not strongly discolourous, upper surface retaining (often copious) cottony hairs, lower surface with loose woolly hairs; apex acute with a short (0.5–1 mm) but distinct mucro; lower- to mid-stem leaves mostly less than 4 cm long; length:width ratio less than or equal to 8; montane to high-alpine sites
Stems woolly at least in leaf-axils; plant perennial
Stems scabrous and minutely glandular-hairy, not woolly; plant annual
Leaf undersides with sessile or shortly stipitate glandular hairs below; leaf-bases broad and stem clasping
Leaf undersides white-wooly; leaf-bases narrow, not stem-clasping
